text: Can anyone explain me how this function works ?? <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/hubl/functions#resize-image-url>
The function generates a CDN recognizable URL that tells the CDN to provide back a resized version of the image based on the parameters provided

<@U015RNVUMRA> You need to set the first sort parameter to True

```{% for content in contents|sort(True, False, 'name') %}

{% endfor %}```

You are resizing a raster image, Reducing the pixel count used to display the image. There will always be a quality loss, which results in a smaller file size.

Set the function to resize to a reasonable size based on the dimensions the image will be displayed atl.

This function should also be treated as a fallback. It is always better to make sure you’re uploading appropriately sized images, as you can have more fine tuned control when resizing an image manually.

The resize_image_url function is like a fallback that you can provide to put guard rails up so that content creators don’t nuke their site load times with gigantic files.

I should also add, if you’re using this with an img element, you should just supply image dimensions using attributes instead of this function as HubSpot will automatically use the height and width to resize the images appropriately.

You did get the expected result

Site search has a dedicated page that should help you to learn more about it. <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/features/content-search>

and does appear in our default module list
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/building-blocks/modules/default-modules#site-search-input>

Let us know if you have further questions
Ok Great!, will try this out and thanks for info :slightly_smiling_face:
got it, thanks. I was expecting to see something here <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/tags>
I reference that 95% of the time. seems like there’s a lot of overlap

There is. Effectively tags were the old way of doing things. When we released the new design manager and custom module system we created module abstractions of the tags so that developers could add them to flexible columns and drag and drop areas. In addition it takes away some of the “magic” of tags since the parameters for the modules are module fields. This is the same as you’d do for a custom module you built.
There are a few cases where tags are still necessary. Specifically forms inside of a custom module, you’ll still use the form tag
This is because modules cannot be nested
Right. Yeah I just built an entire site and used only tags cause I didn’t realize that modules page was even there. The documents have gotten way better, but can always use more love :wink:
Plus when I started, these new docs weren’t a thing

Definitely. Yeah, before I started at HubSpot I pushed for open sourcing the docs because there were things I wanted to update.
<https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/C22PU4LV8/p1544482024218200>
<https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/C22PU4LV8/p1533842428000169?thread_ts=1533842410.000081&cid=C22PU4LV8>

HubSpotters had a different solution in mind - I now work here.  :laughing:

So if you ever find the docs unclear or could use some TLC report it using the on docs feedback tool(pops up every so often) or pop it in this slack and we’ll see what we can do to keep improving it.
